examples.text: They've been best mates since school.
He's a cheat and a gambler; hardly an ideal mate.
He's got loads of mates at school.

definitions.definition: used as a friendly way of addressing somebody, especially between men

examples.text: Sorry mate, you'll have to wait.

definitions.definition: a person you share an activity or accommodation with
the sexual partner of a bird or animal

examples.text: A male bird sings to attract a mate.

definitions.definition: a husband, wife or other sexual partner

examples.text: Many matchmaking sites compile lists of potential mates using basic information.

definitions.definition: a person whose job is to help a worker who has had training in a skill
an officer in a commercial ship below the rank of captain or master
a position in which one player cannot prevent their king (= the most important piece) being captured and therefore loses the game
a situation in which somebody has been completely defeated

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 7 late Middle English: from Middle Low German māt(e) ‘comrade’, of West Germanic origin; related to meat (the underlying concept was of eating together). noun sense 8 Middle English: the noun from Anglo-Norman French mat (from the phrase eschec mat ‘checkmate’); the verb from Anglo-Norman French mater ‘to checkmate’.
